awd_titl_txt: Planning: Connecting Inupiaq and Veterinary Knowledge about Wildlife Diseases and Food Safety
awd_abstract_narration:
Climate change and its impacts on pathogen distribution and traditional storage practices in Alaska have the potential to adversely affect human health and subsistence. This project documents traditional Inupiaq understanding of food safety and knowledge of wildlife diseases in subsistence species common in Northwest Alaska. Combining Indigenous knowledge and veterinary science, the PI team will explore local perspectives on food safety and food-borne illness and knowledge of pathogens in subsistence species. Investigators will assess local interest in the development of a research project dealing with subsistence food safety and collaboratively identify appropriate social scientific, monitoring, and sampling methods to answer community questions. 

Year 1 activities involve virtual and in-person meetings with local residents with an interest in or knowledge of wildlife pathogens in subsistence foods. The PI team will endeavor to include participants familiar with all stages of subsistence animal procurement, processing, and preparation. Using a workshop structure, investigators and participants will discuss Indigenous and veterinary approaches to wildlife pathogens, identifying points of convergence and difference. Should there be sufficient local interest, the PI team will facilitate collaborative development of research questions and identification of appropriate methods, which may include monitoring and sampling, as well as interviewing and participant observation. Ethical aspects of the proposed work will be explicitly addressed, as changes to foodways may have impacts on nutrition and well-being.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Iñupiat of Kotzebue, Alaska, have long relied on wild traditional foods. They hunt, fish, and gather these from the lands and waters of their region. All foods can carry viruses, bacteria, toxins, and other things that can make people sick. We wanted to know what people in Kotzebue look for to reduce the risk of food-borne diseases and increase food safety. We also wanted to compare the ways that people in Kotzebue assess the health of animals and food with the ways that wildlife veterinarians do the same thing. Because we weren’t sure what to expect, this was a planning grant to explore the idea and see if there was interest and value in further research.

Our team included a Tribal employee with extensive experience working with the people of Kotzebue, a social scientist who also has experience with community-based research, and a veterinarian and veterinary pathologist who specialize in wildlife health and disease. 

After reviewing what other studies had been done, we had conversations with several people in Kotzebue who are fully engaged in the traditional food system. These conversations confirmed that people were indeed very interested in the topic, and that they had a lot of knowledge to share about the ways that they assess animal health and the healthfulness of food items. We then enlisted the help of young Iñupiat scholars interested in the topic, to conduct formal interviews with selected Kotzebue residents to learn more about their practices and interests. The interviews included men and women of various ages, to learn about current as well as past practices.

The interviews showed that the people of Kotzebue have many ways of assessing animal and food health. These range from careful observation of the animals they are hunting to choose ones that look healthy, to carefully inspecting meat and other foods after harvest, to various ways of storing and preparing foods. These practices reduce the risk of food-borne disease. For example, frequently stirring seal blubber and allowing for continuous airflow as it renders into seal oil, greatly decreases the chance of botulism toxin developing. 

However, not all pathogens produce visible signs in the animals. In recent years, harmful algal blooms have increased in the waters off Kotzebue. These blooms can produce neurotoxins that cannot be detected by human senses and that are not neutralized by freezing or cooking. Laboratory tests are the only way to detect these toxins. Therefore, it will be important to develop ways of monitoring for emerging pathogens such as harmful algal bloom toxins in the water and marine foods, and sharing that information with people who eat foods from the sea.

We have shared our findings with people in Kotzebue who are likely to be interested in what we learned. These include public health officials, local leaders, and those who participate in traditional food systems. We have also written a manuscript, to share our findings with a larger scientific audience, because Kotzebue is not alone in relying on traditional foods and wanting to ensure the foods remain healthy for those who eat them.

As a planning grant, one of our aims was to identify promising avenues for further research and other activity. A key finding is that the traditional practices for reducing the risk of food-borne disease remain vital and should be supported and shared, especially with younger hunters and fishers. We also recognize the need for further work to document in more detail those practices, and to better understand how they relate to the ways that wildlife veterinarians, public health officials, and others with academic training understand the signs and risks of wildlife disease and the potential for human illness. Finally, we suggest that collaborative monitoring of wildlife health is needed, for both known and emerging pathogens. Collaboration is essential, to harness the deep knowledge of the people of Kotzebue and to make sure that any public messages provide accurate and understandable information. 

We are grateful to the people of Kotzebue for their willingness to work with us on this project.
